data.context: As a group stack. This, for example, encode the Adams-Novikov spectral sequence. (see also [[Thm - Amitsur Cochain as E_1 cotangent complex]]).  Our intent is to show that this provides a geometric setting for $MU$-based synthetic spectra, which then gives a geometric interpretation of the even/motivic filtration e.g. as in [[Notes from Raksit talk]].
**Question**: How does all this interact with [[Cartier-Transforms]]?

data.id: core:Spherical Adjunctions and Prisms.md->core:Brauer groups for omega-monoids.md1
data.context: Hence, $A$ corresponds a *spherical adjunction*, if and only if the kernel $I$ is an invertible object of $V$, this lands us in the setting of [[Brauer groups for omega-monoids]].

In this sense, I sometimes see quantum field theory as the mechanism by which manifold topology controls higher categories. In short, quantum systems living on $(n+1)$-dimensional spacetime manifolds, satisfying a locality principle, encode precisely the algebraic data of $n$-dimensional higher categories. See [[Paradigm - categories as systems]].

- $Spec(R) \to B\mathbb G_m$, a $\mathbb G_m$-torsor (untwisted). Explicitly, this is refining $R$ to a graded ring $R^\bullet$, with $R \simeq \bigoplus_{i \in \mathbb Z} R^i$. See [[#^mou]]
                
---

- A map of graded rings $\mathbb S[\tau] \to R^\bullet$, where $\tau$ is a weight 1 generator. (as in 3.1.4, 3.1.5 in [[#^lur-waldhaus]])
